report_title: Portfolio Management & Investment Advice in the US
executive_summary: The portfolio management and investment advice industry has experienced countervailing trends in the last five years. Rising assets under management (AUM) due to rising asset prices and growing disposable income have increased the base of assets that industry operators charge fees on. However, increased investor preference for passive asset management has driven expenses charged for asset management down. Financial markets play an integral role in AUM growth and base and performance fees earned by managers. Portfolio management and investment advice revenue has been growing at a CAGR of 6.1% over the past five years and is expected to total $543.9 billion in 2024, with profit set to grow to 33.6%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Competition in Portfolio Management and Investment Advice
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Assets under management (AUM) are trending toward a winner-take-all competitive environment, as the portfolio management and investment advice companies with the most assets leverage them to attract additional assets. Large institutional clients flock to the largest portfolio managers and investment advisors since they have better networks and larger resources. This trend is affecting revenue because portfolio managers and investment advisors compete to attract large institutional clients by diminishing fees on investment products.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Consumer Preferences Have Reshaped Funds Management
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Passive investments tend to have lower management expense ratios and have pressured profit potential. The expanding popularity of investment themes, like ESG investing and custom indexing, represents an opportunity for funds management companies as these tend to have higher fees.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Increasing Use of Technology and Data Analytics
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Portfolio management and investment advice firms increasingly use technology and data analytics to identify and evaluate potential investments and monitor and manage existing portfolio companies. This includes using machine learning algorithms to analyze vast amounts of data.

Global economic events like the pandemic and geopolitical tensions have caused turbulence in financial markets, leading to declines in assets under management (AUM). However, central bank policies like quantitative easing have limited further declines.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The trend toward low-fee investment products will continue in the next five years. Assets under management (AUM) for passive funds are expected to continue growing as more investors pour their money into these funds.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Federal Reserve's Fight Against Inflation Means Volatile Interest Rates for the Immediate Future
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As high inflation continues, the FED has indicated it will pursue higher interest rates if necessary. Lower liquidity and investor preference shifts will be the industry's main obstacles. Higher interest rates will benefit portfolio managers and investment advisors dealing with bond products.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Emerging Technologies Like Tokenisation and Quantum Computing Will Revolutionise
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Financial companies are integrating emerging technologies like generative AI, tokenization, and quantum computing to improve customer interactions, market accessibility, processes, and financial simulations. Companies prioritizing digital transformation will have a competitive advantage.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: ESG Investing and the Global Energy Transition Will Be Key Drivers of Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Demand for ESG investing from institutional and retail investors has surged. Methods like direct and custom indexing and thematic investing tend to be more expensive and will be pivotal to profitability and revenue for fund managers as the world transitions to green energy.

industry_definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in managing the portfolio assets (i.e., funds) of others on a fee or commission basis and/or providing customized investment advice to clients on a fee basis. Establishments providing portfolio management have the authority to make investment decisions, and they derive fees based on the size and/or overall performance of the portfolio.
key_trends: The levels of assets under management (AUM) affect market share.
Companies with more AUM get bigger and bigger and let them work with large institutional clients.
Changes in the overall macroeconomic landscape impact market share concentration. The level of interest rates and economic growth affect the amount of capital available for investment.
Assets under management (AUM) are trending toward a winner-take-all competitive environment. High competition pushes companies with the most assets to leverage them to attract additional assets.

As high inflation continues to plague the US economy, the FED has indicated it will pursue higher interest rates in the future. Lower liquidity and investor preference shifts will be the industry's main obstacles in the coming years.
Major companies adapted to higher interest rates and less liquidity. After nearly 15 years of quantities easing, the Federal Reserve is reducing its balance sheet to help control inflation.

Environmental, social and governance (ESG) are becoming more critical to companies. Companies either select to trade investment products based on ESG factors or create a more inclusive and diverse working environment.
Fluctuations in market conditions create volatility. The stock market can soar and push the value of companies up, resulting in booming revenue for portfolio management and investment advisors.
The unexpected changes in regulatory and tax policies can create volatility. New regulations can add compliance costs, chipping away at revenue.

Profit has reacted to fluctuating interest rates. The lower rates in response to the pandemic made debt cheap and pushed investors into the equities market, increasing the value of AUM and the fees that could be charged.
The industry relies on highly skilled investment professionals, including portfolio managers, research analysts and order placement specialists. The need for skilled labor keeps wage costs high.

This region's high concentration of establishments is attributed to its substantial population levels and corporate business activities. This region is generally home to an older population, who use portfolio services at a higher rate.
The high number of industry establishments in the West can be explained by its densely populated cities and advanced capital markets.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Institutional investors like pension funds and endowments investing in equity products.
Institutional investors investing in fixed income products like bonds.
Institutional investors with multi-asset investment portfolios.
Institutional investors focused on alternative investments like hedge funds and private equity.
Individual retail investors, including high-net-worth individuals.

products_and_services.product_description: Alternatives include hedge, private equity, real estate, infrastructure and commodity funds.
Active Core products refer to actively managed investment funds focused on core asset classes like large-cap stocks and government bonds.
Passive products include index funds and exchange-traded funds (ETFs) that track market indices.
Solutions products include target date funds and liability-driven investments tailored to specific investor goals.
Active Specialists manage specialized funds focused on areas like small-cap stocks, emerging markets, or high-yield bonds.
The Other segment consists of various forms of financial planning and advice services.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Large-cap Equity, Government-Fixed Income and Structured Products Will See Growth as Interest Rates Rise
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Large-cap stocks and government fixed-income investments are expected to grow in popularity as higher interest rates make them more attractive relative to other asset classes.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Equity specialties and other fixed income products will face volatility in the coming years
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Specialized equity funds focused on areas like foreign stocks, small-caps, and mid-caps, as well as non-government fixed income products, may face volatility due to changing investor preferences.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Exchange-traded funds and passively managed products are the most popular product line
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Exchange-traded funds (ETFs) and other passively managed investment products have been growing rapidly in popularity, especially among retail investors seeking lower fees.
Alternative investments like hedge funds, private equity, and real estate funds generate significant revenue for the industry due to their higher fee structures.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Solutions Products And Other (Target Data Products And Liability Driven Investments) Are Sustain By Retirees
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Solutions products like target date funds and liability-driven investments aimed at retirees and retirement planning are an important source of demand.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region has the highest concentration of business establishments at 36.4%, attributed to its substantial population levels and corporate business activities.
The West region has 18.2% of establishments, centered mainly in California due to its densely populated cities and advanced capital markets like Silicon Valley.
The Mid-Atlantic region is home to 14.5% of establishments, as it houses many prominent industry players and is near major financial centers like New York City.
The Great Lakes region has 10.9% of establishments and 15.1% of the population.
The Southwest region has 9.1% of establishments and 11.5% of the population.
The Plains region has 5.5% of establishments and 6.8% of the population.
New England has 3.6% of establishments and 4.7% of the population.
The Rocky Mountain region has the lowest percentage of establishments at 1.8% and population at 4.1%.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The SEC administers and enforces federal securities laws to protect investors and maintain fair, honest, efficient securities markets. Congress created the SEC in 1934 to restore and maintain investor confidence after the 1929 stock market crash.

The Investment Company Act regulates the structure and operations of the financial services sector, requiring investment companies to register with the commission and subject their activities to regulation by the commission.
The act requires federal registration of all public securities offerings and provides all prospective investors with a current prospectus. With this act, Congress created the SEC.

The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 requires federal registration of all investment advisers. The act contains various antifraud provisions and requires fund advisers to meet record-keeping, reporting and other requirements.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform & Consumer Protection Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: The 2010 Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act and its key provision, the Volcker Rule, started lawmakers' response to designing a regulatory framework that identifies financial systemic risks and prevents future crises.
The Department of Labor Fiduciary Rule became effective on February 16, 2021, the most critical regulatory change to the industry since the COVID-19 crisis in March 2020.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Regulatory requirements and laws can be complex and difficult for new companies to navigate, making it a barrier to entry into the industry.
The high costs associated with starting a portfolio management and investment advising firm can be a significant barrier for new companies entering the industry.
Established players in the industry often have a strong track record and brand recognition, making it difficult for new companies to differentiate themselves and attract clients.

The industry can be labor-intensive, requiring a significant investment in human capital, including experienced investment professionals, which can be a barrier for new companies entering the industry.

FAQs.question: How do you emphasize the value of your company's services?
FAQs.answer: Portfolio managers emphasize their value by demonstrating over a long period of time they are a trustworthy asset manager.

FAQs.question: What media channels are you using to attract consumers and investors, if any?
FAQs.answer: Portfolio managers, especially those that offer low-cost ETFs, have been particularly fond of using the internet to advertise to would-be customers.

FAQs.question: What international operations do you conduct and how could benefit from increasing your international reach?
FAQs.answer: Since portfolio managers can manage money from anywhere, appreciation of assets globally leads portfolio managers with more assets to manage.

FAQs.question: What is your company doing to reduce costs?
FAQs.answer: Portfolio managers have been outsourcing some mid- and back-office operations in recent years to cut labor expenses.

FAQs.question: How have you taken advantage of rising internet and mobile-internet penetration into the financial services industry?
FAQs.answer: Portfolio managers have benefited from increased marketing to target demographics mobile-internet penetration has afforded them.

FAQs.question: To what extent are your processes automated and how do you plan on investing in automation over the coming years?
FAQs.answer: Automation of mid- and back-office procedures have become increasingly automated in recent years.

FAQs.question: How have the increased capital requirements under Basel III affected operations?
FAQs.answer: Since portfolio managers do not extend loans, Basel III does not affect them.

FAQs.question: Do you have enough capital reserved to be able to invest in new technology/software as soon as it becomes available?
FAQs.answer: Licenses for new software and technology needed by portfolio managers is generally inexpensive.

FAQs.question: How does your profit margin compare to those of your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Profit margins vary widely between portfolio managers based upon the clients they service.

FAQs.question: How do you measure the popularity of your brand? How do you maintain and enhance your reputation in the market?
FAQs.answer: Having a good reputation is affected through strong brand names, the quality and availability of research reports.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay on top of shifting regulations? What costs are associated with governmental compliance?
FAQs.answer: Portfolio managements are among the most regulated organizations in the United States.

FAQs.question: How have fluctuations in interest rates affected sales from your business? How does your company counteract a decrease in interest rates?
FAQs.answer: The prime rate represents the interest rate charged by banks to their most credit-worthy clients.

FAQs.question: How have fluctuations in per capita disposable income affected your company? How do keep track on changes in per capita disposable income?
FAQs.answer: The share of discretionary income indicates the amount of money that is available to be invested.

FAQs.question: Do you closely monitor trends in the S&P 500 and its affect on the industry investment income? Will you be able to increase the value of your assets?
FAQs.answer: Higher share prices drive up industry assets under management.
